{{Infobox person |name = ClÃ©mence PoÃ©sy |image = ClÃ©mence Poesy, People au DÃ©filÃ© Channel, Printemps-EtÃ© 2010.jpg |imagesize = |caption = ClÃ©mence PoÃ©sy in 2009 |birthname = ClÃ©mence Guichard |birth_place = [[L'HaÃ¿-les-Roses]], Paris, France |birth_date = {{birth year and age|1982|10}} |occupation = Actress, model |yearsactive = 1993âpresent }} '''ClÃ©mence PoÃ©sy''' ({{IPA-fr|kleËmÉÌs pÉeËzi}}; born October 1982){{cite video |title=ClÃ©mence PoÃ©sy : interview |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LWhQt6rgMtY |language=French |publisher=ElleadoreTV |time=00:14 |date=Nov 29, 2010 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/63YoWGkeZ |archivedate=November 29, 2011 |quote= NÃ©e la: Octobre 1982, A: [[L'Hay-les-Roses]]}} is a French actress and fashion model. Since starting on the stage as a child, PoÃ©sy had dramatic education, and has been active on both film and television since 1999, including some English-language productions. She is known for roles as [[Fleur Delacour]] in ''[[Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)|Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire]]'' and ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows â Part 1]]'' and ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows â Part 2|Part 2]]'', as ChloÃ« in ''[[In Bruges]]'', and as Rana in ''[[127 Hours]]''. She is also known for her short role as [[List of Gossip Girl characters|Eva Coupeau]] on ''[[Gossip Girl (TV series)|Gossip Girl]]''. ==Early life== Born as '''ClÃ©mence Guichard''' in [[L'HaÃ¿-les-Roses]] a southern suburb of Paris, the daughter of actor/writer [[Ãtienne Guichard]] and a French teacher, PoÃ©sy took her mother's [[maiden name]] as her [[stage name]]. She was sent to an [[alternative school]] in Meudon. She was not the "popular girl" at school, and described herself as maladjusted and "a bit strange".{{cite web |url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/film/clemence-poesy/ |title=Clemence Poesy |first=Olivier |last=Zahm |work=[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]] |accessdate=2011-05-14}} Her father gave PoÃ©sy her first acting job when she was a child; then she had two lines at age 14.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} She has a younger sister, MaÃ«lle PoÃ©sy-Guichard, who is also an actress.{{cite web |url=http://living.scotsman.com/features/Interview-Clemence-Posy-French-model.6294069.jp |title=Interview: Clemence PoÃ©sy, French model and actress |first=Alice |last=Wyllie |date=May 17, 2010 |work=[[The Scotsman]] |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/63Y766wnj |archivedate=November 29, 2011}} ==Career== Since leaving ''La Source'' â the bilingual alternative school she attended at the age of 16{{fact|date=November 2011}} â Poesy has studied drama at ''[[CNSAD|Conservatoire National SupÃ©rieur d'Art Dramatique]]'' (CNSAD) (French National Academy of Dramatic Arts), the ''Atelier International de Blanche Salant et Paul Weaver'',{{fact|date=November 2011}} and the University of [[Nanterre]], where she has since appeared in a number of [[French film]], television, and stage productions.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} Her first English-speaking role was in the [[BBC]] mini-series ''[[Gunpowder, Treason & Plot]]'' (2004), for which she portrayed [[Mary, Queen of Scots]], subsequently winning the 2005 [[Festival International de Programmes Audiovisuels|Golden FIPA]] for actress in a TV Series and Serial.{{cite web |url=http://www.fipa.tm.fr/en/fipa/2005/jury-and-awards-series-and-serials.htm |title=Jury and Awards â Series and Serials â FIPA 2005 |publisher=[[Festival International de Programmes Audiovisuels]] |accessdate=May 14, 2011}} In 2005, PoÃ©sy appeared in the [[Harry Potter (film series)|Harry Potter]] franchise as [[Fleur Delacour]] in ''[[Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)|The Goblet of Fire]]'', and between 2006 and 2007 she starred in a number of film and television productions including the 2007 mini-series ''[[War and Peace (miniseries)|War and Peace]]''. In 2008, Poesy starred in the [[Academy Award]] nominated film ''[[In Bruges]]'', where she acted alongside [[Colin Farrell]], and reunited with ''Harry Potter'' co-stars [[Ralph Fiennes]] and [[Brendan Gleeson]]. In 2009, PoÃ©sy appears in ''[[Heartless (2009 film)|Heartless]]'' opposite [[Jim Sturgess]]. She reprised her role as [[Fleur Delacour]] in both ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows]]'' movies. As a model, PoÃ©sy has been featured in magazines, including the covers of ''[[i-D]]'', twice on French magazine ''Jalouse'', Australian's ''Yen'', and ''[[Nylon (magazine)|Nylon]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.yenmag.net/magazine/back-issues/yen-34/ |title=Yen #34 |date=May 27, 2010 |publisher=''Yen'' |accessdate=May 16, 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.fashionmodeldirectory.com/magazines/jalouse/covers/ |title=Covers of Jalouse - Magazine |publisher=[[fashionmodeldirectory.com]] |accessdate=May 16, 2011}} Since October 2007, Poesy has been one of three spokesmodels for the self-titled fragrance by [[ChloÃ©]], and has modeled in [[Gap (clothing retailer)|Gap]]'s 2008 fall advertising campaign.{{cite web |url=http://www.vogue.fr/mode/en-vogue/diaporama/les-looks-de-clemence-poesy/3330/image/317141 |title=Les looks de ClÃ©mence PoÃ©sy |publisher=[[Vogue Paris|vogue.fr]] |language=French |trans_title=The looks of ClÃ©mence PoÃ©sy |accessdate=May 16, 2011}} She played [[Chuck Bass]]'s new French girlfriend, Eva, in the fourth season of the CW hit show ''[[Gossip Girl (TV series)|Gossip Girl]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Gossip-Girl-Poesy-1019802.aspx|title=Gossip Girl Taps Harry Potter Actress for Recurring Role|publisher=TVGuide.com}} In 2010, Poesy also appeared alongside [[James Franco]] in ''[[127 Hours]]'', directed by [[Danny Boyle]]. ''127 Hours'' was screened at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] on September 12, 2010, following its premiere at the 2010 [[Telluride Film Festival]].{{cite web |title = 127 Hours |url = http://tiff.net/filmsandschedules/tiff/2010/127hours |publisher = [[Toronto International Film Festival]] |year = 2010 |accessdate = August 27, 2010 |archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5sHkTJlJP |archivedate = August 27, 2010 }} In 2011, she appeared alongside [[Rupert Friend]] in ''Lullaby for Pi'', a romantic drama which is Benoit Philipponâs directorial debut. The film is about a jazz singer (Friend) who has just lost his wife and meets a mysterious woman (PoÃ©sy). [[Forest Whitaker]] also starred.{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/lullaby-pi-film-review-58448 |title=Lullaby for Pi -- Film Review |first=Jon |last=Frosch |date=December 9, 2010 |publisher=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |accessdate=May 14, 2011}} She will also be heard singing on the album ''Colour of the Trap'' by [[Miles Kane]]. She is featured on the track "Happenstance".{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/miles-kane/56652 |title=Miles Kane hadn't heard of ClÃ©mence PoÃ©sy before she sang for him |date=May 14, 2011 |publisher=[[NME|nme.com]] |accessdate=May 14, 2011}} ==Filmography== {|class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%;" |- !
